caption_text: The physical model is presented in Fig. 1. The bubbles induce an upward movement of the catalyst. When the bubbles break up, at the bed surface, the solid moves downward, part of it down to the grid.

caption_text: In Fig. 2 the results for fluidizcd-bed heights up to 8 m are plotted. The abscissa is the height of the whole reactor, not the azial coordinate x. The conversion presented in Fig. 2 is the conversion of the gas leaving the reactor.
raw_window: In Fig. 2 the results for fluidizcd-bed heights up to 8 m are plotted.
The abscissa is the height of the whole reactor, not the azial coordinate x.
The conversion presented in Fig. 2 is the conversion of the gas leaving the reactor.

caption_text: The temperature gradient predicted by the model, for the cases investigated in Fig. 2, is moderate, up to 30 C, but for more exothermic reactions it could be by far larger. Larger fluidized-bed heights cause a low temperature which induces a decrease in the conver- sion, as plotted in Fig. 2. For bed heights exceeding 10 m the whole reactor becomes a heat exchanger and there is no more chemical reaction.
raw_window: The temperature gradient predicted by the model, for the cases investigated in Fig. 2, is moderate, up to 30 C, but for more exothermic reactions it could be by far larger.
Larger fluidized-bed heights cause a low temperature which induces a decrease in the conver- sion, as plotted in Fig. 2.
For bed heights exceeding 10 m the whole reactor becomes a heat exchanger and there is no more chemical reaction.

caption_text: The two-phase model pre- dicts a slow increase in the reactant conversion with bed height and the temperature does not seem to reach high values, as presented by the dotted lines in Fig. 2. This comparison shows that the non-isothermal model developed is better suited for fluidized-bed reactors with fast reactions. The model is not too sensitive with respect to the mass and heat transfer coefficients between the jet phase and the grid zones, at least for the range of values reported by Behie and Kehoe (1973) and Behie et at.
raw_window: The two-phase model pre- dicts a slow increase in the reactant conversion with bed height and the temperature does not seem to reach high values, as presented by the dotted lines in Fig. 2.
This comparison shows that the non-isothermal model developed is better suited for fluidized-bed reactors with fast reactions.

The model is not too sensitive with respect to the mass and heat transfer coefficients between the jet phase and the grid zones, at least for the range of values reported by Behie and Kehoe (1973) and Behie et at.

caption_text: The mass and energy balance equations are listed in Table I.
raw_window: The mass and energy balance equations are listed in Table I.

The coefficients for heat and mass transfer between the bubble phase and the dense phase can be computed from Kunii and Levenspiel (1969), considering an average bubble diameter estimated from Mon and Wen (1975).

However, a critical anal ysis of the correlations for interphase mass transfer coefficients has been presented by Chavarie and Grace (1976), while Geldart and Kapoor (1976) studied the bubble size at elevated temperatures.
table_reason: Only S0 mentions the table, S1 and S2 are explanatory sentences not part of the caption.

caption_text: The numerical values and the corresponding units for the parameters used in this paper are listed in Table 2.
raw_window: The numerical values and the corresponding units for the parameters used in this paper are listed in Table 2.
The kinetic parameters k,, and E adopted in this analysis correspond to a fast reaction which could be of interest for an industrial application.
The jet mass and heat transfer coefficients are those reported by Behie and Kehoe (1973) and Behie et at (1975) for a jet corresponding to a grid hole size of 12.7 mm and a jet velocity of 45.7 rn/s.
table_reason: The sentences provide context and description beyond a typical table caption, including references and detailed explanations.
